questions.text: Which of the following muscles contributes to forming both Petit’s triangle and the triangle of auscultation?
questions.explanation:
Triangle of auscultation

Petit’s triangle

Description

The triangle of auscultation is a small gap in the musculature on the back of the thorax present near the inferior angle of the scapula.

Also known as the inferior lumbar triangle.

Borders and contents
  • Superiorly by trapezius muscle (Option D)
  • Inferiorly by latissimus dorsi
  • Laterally by the medial border of scapula
  • The floor has the 6th and 7th ribs and the sixth intercostal space
  • Part of the rhomboid major muscle is exposed in the triangle(Option C)
  • Posteriorly by latissimus dorsi
  • Anteriorly by the posterior border of the external oblique
  • The iliac crest inferiorly forms the base
  • Floor has internal oblique muscle (Option B)
     

Significance

  • The apex of the lower lobe of the lung is found deep to it. When the scapulae move anteriorly (arms folded and trunk flexed), the triangle expands, allowing clear auscultation
  • On the left side, the cardiac orifice of the stomach lies deep, previously used to detect esophageal tumors by auscultating swallowed liquids.
  • A collection of pus from the abdomen may show up here.
  • Site of lumbar hernia.
    M/c site for lumbar hernia: Superior lumbar triangle (Grynfeltt) > Inferior lumbar triangle (Petit)
  • Detaching the fascia from the iliac crest enables access to the retroperitoneal space.

questions.text: All of the following statements about the atlantooccipital joint is/are true except: 1. Allows for flexion and extension of the head 2. It is a synovial condyloid joint 3. Primarily responsible for lateral bending of the head 4. Formed by the articulation between the occipital condyles and the superior articular facets of the atlas 5. It facilitates rotational movement of the head
questions.explanation:
Feature

Atlanto-Occipital Joint

Atlanto-Axial Joint

Location

Between C1 (atlas) and the occipital bone

Between C1 (atlas) and C2 (axis)

Type of Joint

Synovial joint

Synovial joint

Joint Classification

Condyloid joint

Pivot (trochoid) joint

Movement

Flexion/Extension (Nodding "yes")

Rotation (Shaking "no")

Primary Structure

Superior articular facets of atlas

Dens of axis fitting into atlas

Stabilizing Ligaments

Transverse ligament

Transverse ligament

Function

Allows head tilt and nodding movements

Facilitates rotational movement

questions.text: A 5-month-old infant with suspected meningitis is scheduled for a lumbar puncture. Which of the following statements about lumbar puncture in infants is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Procedure is typically done at the L3-L4 intervertebral space.

options.label: B
options.text: Procedure is preferably performed under ultrasound guidance.

options.label: C
options.text: Supracristal plane corresponds to the L4-L5 vertebral level.

options.label: D
options.text: Depth to the subarachnoid space is approximately 1.4 cm in neonates.

questions.correct_answer: C. Supracristal plane corresponds to the L4-L5 vertebral level.
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Adults

Neonates and infants

Spinal Cord Termination

Terminates at the level of L1-L2.

Terminates between L1 and L3 in neonates.

Conus Medullaris Location

Around the L1 and L2 lumbar vertebra and can sometimes be lower.

Commonly at the lower third of L1 vertebral body (range: lower third of T12 to L2/L3 intervertebral disc).

Supracristal Plane
  • A line between the highest points of the iliac crests intersects the vertebral column around L4 or the L4/L5 intervertebral disc; this may vary from the L2/L3 to L5/S1 level.
  • In most adults, the plane intersects the vertebral column inferior to the termination of the spinal cord.

Intersects the vertebral column at L3-L4 level in children. It may vary from L2/L3 to L5/S1 interspinous space. (Option C)

Ultrasound Guidance

Not routinely used.

May be preferable to avoid overlap between the supracristal plane and the termination of the spinal cord. (Option B)

Positioning
  • Patients can be seated or lying on their side (lateral decubitus) on a firm, flat surface.
  • Flex the lumbar spine to separate the vertebral spines maximally and expose the ligamentum flavum.

Infants should be positioned to maximize convex curvature to the lumbar spine, either lying or sitting.

 

Needle Insertion

Insert the needle between the spines of L3 and L4 or L4 and L5, and anesthetize the skin and soft tissues.
  • Performed between spinous processes of either L3 and L4 or L4 and L5, using a trocar needle and into subarachnoid space below the level of conus medullaris. (Option A)
  • Depth to Subarachnoid Space: Approximately 1.4 cm in neonates, increasing with age. (Option D)

Needle Puncturing

Needle Path

Technique
  • Lumbar puncture needle inserted in the midline or just to one side.
  • Angle the needle in the horizontal and sagittal planes to pierce the ligamentum flavum in or near the midline.
  • Slight loss of resistance as the needle enters the epidural space.
  • Careful advancement to pierce the dura and arachnoid to release CSF.

questions.text: Based on the image, which of the following structures is primarily responsible for facilitating the described movement of the head?
questions.explanation:
C1 Vertebra (Atlas)

C2 Vertebra (Axis)
 

Body
  • Lacks a traditional vertebral body.
  • Consists of an anterior and posterior arch.

Prominent body with a unique projection called the odontoid process (dens).

Odontoid process: Bony projection that fits into the atlas ring, allowing for rotational movement of the head and neck.

Spine

Lacks spine

The spine is massive with a bifid tip

Superior Articular Facets

Articulate with the occipital condyles of the skull (atlantooccipital joint)

Articulate with the inferior facets of the atlas (atlantoaxial joint); oriented to permit head rotation.

Inferior Articular Facets

Articulates with C2 (atlantoaxial joint)

Articulates with C3

Transverse process
  • Long transverse process.
  • Has anterior and posterior tubercles for ligament and muscle attachments.
  • Small transverse processes.
  • Lacks anterior tubercle.

Transverse Foramen

Contains a transverse foramen for the passage of the vertebral artery

Role and Movement

Supports the skull; allows nodding movements (flexion and extension) of the head.

Yes movement

Crucial for head rotation; the dens serves as the central pivot point.

No movement

Special Note

Distinct for lacking a vertebral body and spinous process.

Provides stability and acts as the primary pivot for head rotation.

questions.text: Assertion (A): There are 8 cervical spinal nerves despite there being only 7 cervical vertebrae. Reason (R): The first cervical nerve exits above the first cervical vertebra, and the remaining nerves exit below their corresponding vertebrae.

options.label: A
options.text: Both Assertion and Reason are correct, and the Reason is the correct explanation for the Assertion

options.label: B
options.text: Both Assertion and Reason are correct, but the Reason is not the correct explanation for the Assertion

options.label: C
options.text: The Assertion is correct, but the Reason is incorrect

options.label: D
options.text: The Assertion is incorrect, but the Reason is correct

questions.correct_answer: A. Both Assertion and Reason are correct, and the Reason is the correct explanation for the Assertion
questions.explanation:
Regions

Number of Vertebrae

Spinal Nerves (Pairs)

Cervical

7

8

Thoracic

12

12

Lumbar

5

5

Sacral

5

5

Coccygeal

4 (varies)

1

Total

33 vertebrae

31 pairs

questions.text: An anatomy professor presents an image of the back region and asks to identify the nerve innervation of muscle marked in green?

options.label: C
options.text: From the dorsal rami of C1

questions.explanation:
Muscle

Muscle connecting

Origin

Insertion

Action

Nerve supply

Trapezius

Vertebral column to scapula

Thoracic vertebrae

Spines of cervical and lateral 1/3 of clavicle +

acromion and spine of scapula

Rotation of the scapula during abduction of the humerus overhead.

It is made up of 3 fibers:

1- Middle fibres: Retract scapula

2- Upper fibres: Elevate the scapula.

3- Lower fibres: Depress scapula.

Accessory nerve

(11th cranial nerve)

Rhomboid

major & minor

Vertebral column to scapula

Thoracic spines

Medial border of the scapula.

Retract scapula.

Dorsal scapular nerve.

Levator scapulae

Vertebral column to scapula

Cervical transverse processes

Medial border of the scapula.

Elevates scapula

Dorsal scapular nerve.

Latissimus dorsi

Vertebral column to

Humerus

Spines of thoracic vertebrae

Bicipital groove of the humerus.

Extension, adduction & medial rotation of humerus.

Thoracodorsal nerve

questions.text: By the end of fetal development, at which vertebral level does the spinal cord terminate?
A 54-year-old female is a known case of rheumatoid arthritis, underwent MRI which showed tectorial membrane thickening. This structure is derived from which of the following ligaments?
Match the right options. a Spine of scapula i T2 b Highest point of iliac crest ii T3 c Superior angle of scapula iii T7 d Inferior angle of scapula iv L4
questions.explanation:
Parts of scapula

Corresponding vertebrae

Spine

T3 (spinous process)

Superior angle

T2

Inferior angle

T7

Other important landmarks

  

Highest point of iliac crest

L4

Posterior-superior iliac spine

S2

questions.text: Which of the following is true about cauda equina?

options.label: A
options.text: It is comprised of the terminal end of the spinal cord

options.label: B
options.text: Ends at L1-L2 vertebra in adults

options.label: C
options.text: Surrounded by CSF in the subarachnoid space

options.label: D
options.text: The filum terminale begins from the apex of cauda equina

questions.correct_answer: C. Surrounded by CSF in the subarachnoid space

Cauda Equina

Conus Medullaris

Definition

A bundle of spinal nerve roots resembling a horse's tail (Option A)

The tapered end of the spinal cord

Location

Below the conus medullaris, in the vertebral canal

At the lower end of the spinal cord

Structure

Composed of dorsal and ventral nerve roots from L2 to S5 and Co1

Comprised of the terminal end of the spinal cord

Number of Nerve Roots

40 nerve roots (16 lumbar, 20 sacral, 4 coccygeal)

None; terminates without forming new roots

Formation of Spinal Nerves

Dorsal and ventral roots join at intervertebral foramina

Does not contribute to new spinal nerves

Filum Terminale

Surrounds cauda equina

Attached to the apex of conus medullaris (Option D)

Clinical Relevance

Site for lumbar puncture; potential for cauda equina syndrome

Indicates termination of spinal cord; important for anatomical reference

Length

Extends to the sacral region, around 15-20 cm (Option B)

Generally ends at L1-L2 vertebrae in adults

Surrounding Structures

Surrounded by cerebrospinal fluid in the subarachnoid space

Encased by pia mater; continuous with filum terminale

Anatomical Changes with Age

Remains relatively constant

Position shifts upward in younger individuals

 

Cauda equina syndrome

Conus medullaris syndrome

Location of Injury

Cauda equina (nerve roots below L1/L2)

S2–S4 segments of the spinal cord

Type of Paralysis

Lower motor neuron signs (flaccid paralysis)

Upper motor neuron signs (spasticity)

Sensory Symptoms

Root pain and sensory loss in the lower limbs

Anesthesia in the perineum

Bladder and Bowel Involvement

Late involvement (due to damage to nerve roots)

Early involvement (due to sacral parasympathetic nerves)

Sexual Function

Can be affected (if involved nerve roots are damaged)

Affected (due to involvement of S2–S4 nerves)

Reflexes

Absent reflexes (due to lower motor neuron damage)

Absent or reduced reflexes

Onset of Symptoms

Gradual onset

Sudden onset

questions.text: A 42-year-old male presents with complaints of lower back pain radiating down his left leg, associated with numbness over the top of his foot and difficulty in dorsiflexing his big toe. On examination, he has weakness in the extension of the great toe and decreased sensation along the dorsum of the foot. Reflexes are normal. Based on the symptoms, which vertebral level is most likely affected?
questions.explanation:
Herniated Disc Between

Compressed Nerve Root

Symptoms (Upper Limb)

C4 and C5

C5

Shoulder pain, weakness in deltoid muscle

C5 and C6

C6

Pain in biceps, weakness in wrist extension

C6 and C7

C7

Triceps weakness, difficulty extending the elbow

C7 and T1

C8

Hand weakness, difficulty with finger movements

Herniated Disc Between

Compressed Nerve Root

Symptoms (Lower Limb)

L3 and L4

L4

Weakness in knee extension, reduced patellar reflex

L4 and L5

L5

Weakness in foot dorsiflexion, difficulty walking

L5 and S1

S1

Pain down the back of the leg, reduced Achilles reflex, foot drop

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought in for a routine check-up. The parents have noticed a pronounced lumbar curvature since the child began walking. Which of the following best describes this lumbar curvature?

options.label: D
options.text: Curvature related to increased abdominal weight

questions.explanation:
Primary Curvature

Secondary Curvature
  • Developmental.
  • Thoracic and sacral kyphosis (both concave anteriorly) are primary curvatures. (Option A & C)
  • Develop during the fetal period in response to the flexed fetal position.
  • Are in the same direction as the main curvatures of the fetal vertebral column.
  • Retained throughout life due to differences in height between the anterior and posterior parts of the vertebrae.
  • Acquired in relation to the erect human posture.
  • Cervical and lumbar lordosis (both concave posteriorly) are secondary curvatures.
  • Result from extension from the flexed fetal position.
  • Begin to appear during the late fetal period but do not become obvious until infancy (roughly, 1st year).
  • Secondary curvatures are primarily maintained by differences in the thickness between the anterior and posterior parts of the intervertebral (IV) discs.
  • Cervical lordosis becomes evident when an infant begins to raise (extend) the head while prone and to hold the head up while sitting.
  • Lumbar lordosis appears when toddlers (children learning to walk) begin to assume upright posture, standing and walking. It is more pronounced in females. (Option B)

questions.text: A patient has restricted spinal rotation and lateral flexion. Which vertebral structure primarily functions as a lever for these movements?
questions.explanation:
Typical Vertebra

Has a ventral body, dorsal arch with processes, and a vertebral foramen.

Image

Vertebral Body
  • Adjacent vertebral bodies are connected by fibrocartilage discs.
  • Form a flexible, weight-supporting central axis.
  • Transmits even greater forces generated from attached muscles.

Vertebral Arch

  • Consists of pedicles and a broader laminae.
  • Transverse, superior, and inferior articular processes project from the junction of the pedicle and lamina.

Vertebral Foramina
  • Formed by the vertebral arch and body.
  • Contains the spinal cord, meninges and their vessels.

Intervertebral Foramina
  • Located between adjoining vertebrae, near junctions of vertebral bodies and arches.
  • Transmit mixed spinal nerves, small recurrent nerves, and blood and lymphatic vessels.

Spinous Processes

(Option A)
  • Project dorsally from the junction of the lamina.
  • Act as levers for muscles that control posture and active movements (flexion/extension, lateral flexion and rotation) of the vertebral column.

Transverse Processes

(Option D)
  • Project laterally from the pediculolaminar junctions.
  • Serve as levers for muscles and ligaments, mainly concerned with rotation and lateral flexion.

Articular Processes

(Option B & C)
  • Superior articular processes project cranially with dorsal facets; inferior articular processes project caudally with ventral facets.
  • They form zygapophysial or facet joints and form part of the posterior boundaries of intervertebral foramina, permitting only limited vertebral movement.

Trabecular Structure
  • Vertebrae are internally composed of trabecular bone with an outer shell of compact bone perforated by vascular foramina.
  • Trabecular interior contains red bone marrow and basivertebral veins.

questions.text: An anatomy professor presents an image of a vertebra in class and asks the students to identify its type. Which type of vertebra is depicted in the image?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Cervical Vertebrae (Option A)

Thoracic Vertebrae (Option B)

Lumbar Vertebrae

(Option C)

Image

Size

Small size

Intermediate-size

Large size

Body

Small, broad with a convex anterior surface.

Waisted cylinder; nearly equal transverse and AP dimensions.

Wider transversely

Vertebral Canal

Triangular

Small and circular

Triangular

Pedicles and Laminae

Pedicles: Attach midway between the discal surface of the vertebral body.

Lamina: Thin, slightly curved.

Pedicles: Do not diverge as the vertebral foramen is small and circular

Lamina: Short, thick, and broad.

Pedicles: Short

Laminae: Broad and short.

Spinous Process

Short, bifid with two unequal tubercles.

Slants downward.

Almost horizontal, quadrangular, and thickened along its posterior and inferior borders.

Transverse Process

Composite structure

Large, club-like.

Long, thin.

Superior Articular Facets

Flat and ovoid, directed superoposteriorly.

Directed posteriorly and slightly superolaterally.

Bear vertical concave facets facing posteromedially.

Inferior Articular Facets

Directed mainly anteriorly.

Directed forwards and slightly superomedially.

Have vertical convex articular facets facing anterolaterally.

Special Features

Foramen Transversarium: Transmits the vertebral artery and vein, and a branch from the cervicothoracic ganglion (vertebral nerve) except in the seventh cervical vertebra.

Have lateral costal facets and transverse process facets for rib articulation.

Costal facets and transverse foramina are absent.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient undergoes spinal surgery. Postoperatively, he develops a cerebrospinal fluid leak. Which space is most likely compromised?
questions.explanation:
Epidural Space (Option A)

Subdural Space

Subarachnoid Space
  • Located between the spinal dura mater and the periosteum.
  • Contains:
    • Loose areolar tissue
    • Semiliquid fat
    • Spinal arteries supplying deeper structures
    • Internal vertebral venous plexus.
  • Epidural anesthesia is given here
  • Potential space between the dura and arachnoid mater. (Option B)
  • Contains a thin layer of serous fluid.
  • Allows movement of the dura over the arachnoid.
  • Extends onto spinal nerves and connects with lymphatic spaces.
  • Wide space between pia mater and arachnoid mater.
  • Filled with cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). (Option C)
  • Cushions the brain and spinal cord.
  • Wider in the spinal region, especially below the spinal cord where it encloses the cauda equina.
  • Lumbar punctures are typically performed between L3 & L4 vertebrae.

questions.text: A patient undergoes a procedure affecting a delicate, thread-like structure extending from the conus medullaris to the coccyx as marked in the figure. Which of the following statements regarding this structure is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: It is composed mainly of dura mater and contains no nerve fibers

options.label: B
options.text: Distal part of it is called the coccygeal ligament.

options.label: C
options.text: It does not extend beyond the sacral hiatus

options.label: D
options.text: It measures about 50 cm in length

questions.correct_answer: B. Distal part of it is called the coccygeal ligament.

questions.text: Which of the following spinal segments is located between the cervical enlargement of the spinal cord?
questions.explanation:
Cervical Enlargement

Lumbar Enlargement

Extent

C5 to T1 spinal segments (Option B)

L2 to S3 spinal segments (Option C)

Function

Gives rise to the brachial plexus

Contributes to the lumbar plexus

Corresponding vertebral level

C3 to T1 vertebrae. (Option D)

T9 to L1 vertebrae. (Option A)
